title: Elucidating the Polar Structure of Twinned Domains in BiInO3 Using Electron Ptychography
content: Bismuth-based perovskite materials have received growing interest as an alternative to lead-based oxides for a range of applications, such as piezoelectrics, ferroelectrics, spintronics, and optoelectronic devices. [1]. Among these materials, the interest in BiInO3 is steadily growing [1-3]. Due to the polar structure of BiInO3 (LiNbO3-type) [4], twin domains readily form during the cooling process post-growth, involving phase transformations from a high-temperature non-polar to a low-temperature polar phase. The reduced dimensionality and distinct chemical and structural characteristics at the domain walls hold the potential to significantly impact device performance [5]. Therefore, a thorough multiscale characterization becomes imperative.
